gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
Module name: mcb_raw_wrapper

Explanation: This module is a wrapper for a Memory Controller Block (MCB) interface. It handles the connection between the user interface and the actual memory device (likely DDR/DDR2/DDR3 SDRAM). The module includes functionality for address and data management, clock generation, and I/O operations. It supports various memory configurations and uses IODRP2 (I/O Digital Reconfiguration Port) components for calibration and timing adjustments. The wrapper also includes logic for different port configurations, data widths, and memory types, making it adaptable to various memory interface requirements.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
Input ports:
sysclk_2x, sysclk_2x_180, pll_ce_0, pll_ce_90, pll_lock, sys_rst, p0_arb_en, p0_cmd_clk, p0_cmd_en, p0_cmd_instr, p0_cmd_bl, p0_cmd_byte_addr, p0_wr_clk, p0_wr_en, p0_wr_mask, p0_wr_data, p0_rd_clk, p0_rd_en, p1_arb_en, p1_cmd_clk, p1_cmd_en, p1_cmd_instr, p1_cmd_bl, p1_cmd_byte_addr, p1_wr_clk, p1_wr_en, p1_wr_mask, p1_wr_data, p1_rd_clk, p1_rd_en, p2_arb_en, p2_cmd_clk, p2_cmd_en, p2_cmd_instr, p2_cmd_bl, p2_cmd_byte_addr, p2_wr_clk, p2_wr_en, p2_wr_mask, p2_wr_data, p2_rd_clk, p2_rd_en, p3_arb_en, p3_cmd_clk, p3_cmd_en, p3_cmd_instr, p3_cmd_bl, p3_cmd_byte_addr, p3_wr_clk, p3_wr_en, p3_wr_mask, p3_wr_data, p3_rd_clk, p3_rd_en, p4_arb_en, p4_cmd_clk, p4_cmd_en, p4_cmd_instr, p4_cmd_bl, p4_cmd_byte_addr, p4_wr_clk, p4_wr_en, p4_wr_mask, p4_wr_data, p4_rd_clk, p4_rd_en, p5_arb_en, p5_cmd_clk, p5_cmd_en, p5_cmd_instr, p5_cmd_bl, p5_cmd_byte_addr, p5_wr_clk, p5_wr_en, p5_wr_mask, p5_wr_data, p5_rd_clk, p5_rd_en, calib_recal, selfrefresh_enter, ui_read, ui_add, ui_cs, ui_clk, ui_sdi, ui_addr, ui_broadcast, ui_drp_update, ui_done_cal, ui_cmd, ui_cmd_in, ui_cmd_en, ui_dqcount, ui_dq_lower_dec, ui_dq_lower_inc, ui_dq_upper_dec, ui_dq_upper_inc, ui_udqs_inc, ui_udqs_dec, ui_ldqs_inc, ui_ldqs_dec.

Explanation: These inputs control the memory controller's operation, including clock signals, command inputs, data inputs, and configuration signals for up to 6 ports (p0 to p5). They also include calibration and UI (User Interface) related inputs.

Output ports:
p0_cmd_empty, p0_cmd_full, p0_wr_full, p0_wr_empty, p0_wr_count, p0_wr_underrun, p0_wr_error, p0_rd_data, p0_rd_full, p0_rd_empty, p0_rd_count, p0_rd_overflow, p0_rd_error, p1_cmd_empty, p1_cmd_full, p1_wr_full, p1_wr_empty, p1_wr_count, p1_wr_underrun, p1_wr_error, p1_rd_data, p1_rd_full, p1_rd_empty, p1_rd_count, p1_rd_overflow, p1_rd_error, p2_cmd_empty, p2_cmd_full, p2_wr_full, p2_wr_empty, p2_wr_count, p2_wr_underrun, p2_wr_error, p2_rd_data, p2_rd_full, p2_rd_empty, p2_rd_count, p2_rd_overflow, p2_rd_error, p3_cmd_empty, p3_cmd_full, p3_wr_full, p3_wr_empty, p3_wr_count, p3_wr_underrun, p3_wr_error, p3_rd_data, p3_rd_full, p3_rd_empty, p3_rd_count, p3_rd_overflow, p3_rd_error, p4_cmd_empty, p4_cmd_full, p4_wr_full, p4_wr_empty, p4_wr_count, p4_wr_underrun, p4_wr_error, p4_rd_data, p4_rd_full, p4_rd_empty, p4_rd_count, p4_rd_overflow, p4_rd_error, p5_cmd_empty, p5_cmd_full, p5_wr_full, p5_wr_empty, p5_wr_count, p5_wr_underrun, p5_wr_error, p5_rd_data, p5_rd_full, p5_rd_empty, p5_rd_count, p5_rd_overflow, p5_rd_error, mcbx_dram_addr, mcbx_dram_ba, mcbx_dram_ras_n, mcbx_dram_cas_n, mcbx_dram_we_n, mcbx_dram_cke, mcbx_dram_clk, mcbx_dram_clk_n, mcbx_dram_dq, mcbx_dram_dqs, mcbx_dram_dqs_n, mcbx_dram_udqs, mcbx_dram_udqs_n, mcbx_dram_udm, mcbx_dram_ldm, mcbx_dram_odt, mcbx_dram_ddr3_rst, uo_data, uo_data_valid, uo_done_cal, uo_cmd_ready_in, uo_refrsh_flag, uo_cal_start, uo_sdo, status, selfrefresh_mode.

Explanation: These outputs provide status information for each port (p0 to p5), including command and data buffer status, error flags, and read data. They also include memory interface signals (mcbx_dram_*) for controlling the external memory device, and various status and calibration outputs (uo_*).

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
Based on the provided code, here are the internal signals and their explanations:

Internal signals: MCB_SYSRST, int_sys_rst, syn_uiclk_pll_lock, syn1_sys_rst, syn2_sys_rst, selfrefresh_enter_r1, selfrefresh_enter_r2, selfrefresh_enter_r3, gated_pll_lock, soft_cal_selfrefresh_req, wait_200us_counter, cke_train_reg, wait_200us_done_r1, wait_200us_done_r2, normal_operation_window, DONE_SOFTANDHARD_CAL, cke_train.

Explanation:
1. MCB_SYSRST: System reset signal for the Memory Controller Block.
2. int_sys_rst: Internal system reset signal.
3. syn_uiclk_pll_lock: Synchronized PLL lock signal for UI clock.
4. syn1_sys_rst, syn2_sys_rst: Synchronization registers for system reset.
5. selfrefresh_enter_r1, selfrefresh_enter_r2, selfrefresh_enter_r3: Registers for self-refresh entry signal synchronization.
6. gated_pll_lock: Gated PLL lock signal.
7. soft_cal_selfrefresh_req: Soft calibration self-refresh request signal.
8. wait_200us_counter: Counter for 200us wait period.
9. cke_train_reg: Register for CKE (Clock Enable) training.
10. wait_200us_done_r1, wait_200us_done_r2: Registers for 200us wait completion signal.
11. normal_operation_window: Signal indicating normal operation window.
12. DONE_SOFTANDHARD_CAL: Signal indicating completion of soft and hard calibration.
13. cke_train: Clock Enable training signal.

These internal signals are used for various purposes such as reset management, synchronization, self-refresh control, calibration, and timing management within the Memory Controller Block wrapper.
